00049 // EventType Description
00050 //
00051 // Data necessary to register and event classification
00052 //
00053 // This is used as auxillary data during event handler
00054 // registration, but also provides the translation from internal
00055 // numeric event type designation to a human readible identifier
00056 // useful for debugging and logging.
00057 //
00058 // Note: During event handler registration, it is wrong code to
00059 // register an event type that has different text associated with
00060 // the numeric identifier.
00061 //
00062 // The event manager generates a 32-biy numeric identity for this
00063 // event type upon registration and that is what is used by the
00064 // system from that point out.
00065 
00066 // Use this event type to register a listener that receives ( but
00067 // never eats ) all events that pass through the system. It is
00068 // special in that if the type ident str that is passed in
00069 // matches this, then the ident value is set to zero.
00070 
00071 char const * const kpWildcardEventType = "*";
00072 
00073 
00074 
00075 class EventType
00076 {
00077 public:
00078 
00079         explicit EventType( char const * const pIdentStr )
00080                 : m_ident( hash_name(pIdentStr) ),
00081                 m_identStr(pIdentStr)
00082         {}
00083 
00084         unsigned long getIdent() const
00085         {
00086                 return reinterpret_cast<unsigned long>(m_ident);
00087         }
00088 
00089         char const * const getStr() const
00090         {
00091                 return m_identStr;
00092         }
00093 
00094         bool operator< ( EventType const & o ) const
00095         {
00096                 bool r = ( getIdent() < o.getIdent() );
00097                 return r;
00098         }
00099 
00100         bool operator== ( EventType const & o ) const
00101         {
00102                 bool r = ( getIdent() == o.getIdent() );
00103                 return r;
00104         }
00105 
00106         static
00107         void * hash_name( char const *  pIdentStr );
00108 
00109 private:
00110 
00111         // note: m_ident is stored as a void* not an int, so that in
00112         // the debugger it will show up as hex-values instead of
00113         // integer values. This is a bit more representative of what
00114         // we're doing here and makes it easy to allow external code
00115         // to assign event types as desired.
00116 
00117         void *       m_ident;
00118         char const * m_identStr;
00119         
00120 };
00121 
00122 // IEventData Description
00123 //
00124 // Base type for event object hierarchy, may be used itself for
00125 // simplest event notifications ... aka:those that do not carry
00126 // additional payload data. If any event needs to propogate with
00127 // payload data it must be defined separately.
00128 //
00129 // The userData parameter is used to propogate access from
00130 // event-firing code to event-listening code. By using a smart
00131 // pointer object here you can safely create-and-forget the
00132 // object at event trigger time, and if there is nothing to
00133 // associate with the event then simply provde the parameter with
00134 // EventData(NULL) and away you go ... all nice and safe and
00135 // zero-memory bleed.
00136 
00137 class IEventData
00138 {
00139 public:
00140         virtual ~IEventData()   { }
00141 };
00142 
00143 template < typename T >
00144 struct EvtData : public IEventData
00145 {
00146 private:
00147         EvtData();                                      // disable default construction
00148         EvtData(const EvtData &);       // disable copy construction
00149         T m_Value;
00150 
00151 public:
00152         explicit EvtData<T>( T n )
00153         {
00154                 m_Value = n;
00155         }
00156 
00157         const T GetValue() { return m_Value; }
00158 };
00159 
00160 typedef EvtData<int> EvtData_Int;
00161 
00162 typedef boost::shared_ptr<IEventData> IEventDataPtr;
00163

00165 // Event Description
00166 //
00167 // This is a base class that 
00168 //
00169

00171 
00172 class Event
00173 {
00174 public:
00175 
00176         explicit Event( char const * const inEventTypeName,
00177                                            float inTime = 0.f,
00178                                            IEventDataPtr inData =
00179                                                 IEventDataPtr((IEventData*)NULL) )
00180                 : m_type( inEventTypeName ),
00181                   m_time( inTime ),
00182                   m_userData( inData )
00183         {}
00184 
00185         Event( Event const & o )
00186                 : m_type( o.m_type ),
00187                 m_time( o.m_time ),
00188                 m_userData( o.m_userData )
00189         {}
00190 
00191         virtual ~Event()
00192         {}
00193 
00194         EventType const & getType() const
00195         {
00196                 return m_type;
00197         }
00198         
00199         float getTime() const
00200         {
00201                 return m_time;
00202         }
00203 
00204         IEventDataPtr getData() const
00205         {
00206                 return m_userData;
00207         }
00208 
00209         template<typename _T>
00210         _T * getDataPtr() const
00211         {
00212                 return reinterpret_cast<_T *>( m_userData.get() );
00213         }
00214 
00215         // two methods added for the network chapter
00216         void setDataPtr(IEventDataPtr userData) { m_userData = userData; }
00217         virtual void serialize(std::ostrstream &out) const { };         
00218         
00219 private:
00220         
00221         EventType  m_type;     // the identified type of the event
00222         float         m_time;     // the time at which the event fired
00223         IEventDataPtr m_userData; // the call-time provided associated
00224                                                           // data link ( may be NULL, validly,
00225                                                           // if no associated data )
00226 
00227 };
00228 
00229 // IEventListener Description
00230 //
00231 // Base type for all event handler objects, note tht this is a
00232 // C++ interface in the classic sense in that it defines the call
00233 // sequence but does not provide any functionality nor aggregate
00234 // any data.
00235 //
00236 // Thus, this is suitable for both single-inheritance use and MAY
00237 // be used safely in a mutiple-inheritance construct, neither is
00238 // imposed or assumed.
00239 
00240 class IEventListener
00241 {
00242 public:
00243 
00244         explicit IEventListener()
00245         {}
00246 
00247         virtual ~IEventListener()
00248         {}
00249 
00250         // Returns ascii-text name for this listener, used mostly for
00251         // debugging
00252 
00253         virtual char const * GetName(void) = 0;
00254 
00255         // Return 'false' to indicate that this listener did NOT
00256         // consume the event, ( and it should continue to be
00257         // propogated )
00258         //                                      
00259         // return 'true' to indicate that this listener consumed the
00260         //event, ( and it should NOT continue to be propgated )
00261 
00262         virtual bool HandleEvent( Event const & event ) = 0
00263         {               
00264                 // Note: while HandleEvent() MUST be implemented in all
00265                 // derivative classes, (as this function is pure-virtual
00266                 // and thus the hook for IEventListener being an
00267                 // interface definition) a base implementation is
00268                 // provided here to make it easier to wire up do-nothing
00269                 // stubs that can easily be wired to log the
00270                 // unhandled-event (once logging is available)
00271 
00272                 // HandleEvent() functioning should be kept as brief as
00273                 // possible as multiple events will need to be evaluated
00274                 // per-frame in many cases.
00275         }
00276 };
00277 
00278 // IEventManager Description
00279 //
00280 // This is the object which maintains the list of registered
00281 // events and their listeners
00282 //
00283 // This is a many-to-many relationship, as both one listener can
00284 // be configured to process multiple event types and of course
00285 // multiple listeners can be registered to each event type.
00286 //
00287 // The interface to this contruct uses smart pointer wrapped
00288 // objects, the purpose being to ensure that no object that the
00289 // registry is referring to is destoyed before it is removed from
00290 // the registry AND to allow for the registry to be the only
00291 // place where this list is kept ... the application code does
00292 // not need to maintain a second list.
00293 //
00294 // Simply tearing down the registry (e.g.: destroying it) will
00295 // automatically clean up all pointed-to objects ( so long as
00296 // there are no other oustanding references, of course ).
00297 
00298 typedef boost::shared_ptr<IEventListener>   EventListenerPtr;
00299 
00300 typedef boost::shared_ptr<Event>           EventPtr;
00301 
00302 class IEventManager
00303 {
00304 public:
00305 
00306         enum eConstants
00307         {
00308                 kINFINITE = 0xffffffff
00309         };
00310 
00311         explicit IEventManager( char const * const pName,
00312                                                                            bool setAsGlobal );
00313         
00314         virtual ~IEventManager();
00315 
00316         // Register a handler for a specific event type, implicitly
00317         // the event type will be added to the known event types if
00318         // not already known.
00319         //
00320         // The function will return false on failure for any
00321         // reason. The only really anticipated failure reason is if
00322         // the input event type is bad ( e.g.: known-ident number
00323         // with different signature text, or signature text is empty
00324         // )
00325         
00326         virtual bool addListener ( EventListenerPtr const & inHandler,
00327                                                            EventType const & inType ) = 0;
00328 
00329         // Remove a listener/type pairing from the internal tables
00330         //
00331         // Returns false if the pairing was not found.
00332         
00333         virtual bool delListener ( EventListenerPtr const & inHandler,
00334                                                            EventType const & inType ) = 0;
00335 
00336         // Fire off event - synchronous - do it NOW kind of thing -
00337         // analogous to Win32 SendMessage() API.
00338         //
00339         // returns true if the event was consumed, false if not. Note
00340         // that it is acceptable for all event listeners to act on an
00341         // event and not consume it, this return signature exists to
00342         // allow complete propogation of that shred of information
00343         // from the internals of this system to outside uesrs.
00344 
00345         virtual bool trigger ( Event const & inEvent ) const = 0;
00346 
00347         // Fire off event - asynchronous - do it WHEN the event
00348         // system tick() method is called, normally at a judicious
00349         // time during game-loop processing.
00350         //
00351         // returns true if the message was added to the processing
00352         // queue, false otherwise.
00353 
00354         virtual bool queueEvent ( EventPtr const & inEvent ) = 0;
00355 
00356         // Find the next-available instance of the named event type
00357         // and remove it from the processing queue.
00358         //
00359         // This may be done up to the point that it is actively being
00360         // processed ...  e.g.: is safe to happen during event
00361         // processing itself.
00362         //
00363         // if 'allOfType' is input true, then all events of that type
00364         // are cleared from the input queue.
00365         //
00366         // returns true if the event was found and removed, false
00367         // otherwise
00368 
00369         virtual bool abortEvent ( EventType const & inType,
00370                                                           bool allOfType = false ) = 0;
00371 
00372         // Allow for processing of any queued messages, optionally
00373         // specify a processing time limit so that the event
00374         // processing does not take too long. Note the danger of
00375         // using this artificial limiter is that all messages may not
00376         // in fact get processed.
00377         //
00378         // returns true if all messages ready for processing were
00379         // completed, false otherwise (e.g. timeout )
00380 
00381         virtual bool tick ( unsigned long maxMillis = kINFINITE ) = 0;
00382 
00383         // --- information lookup functions ---
00384         
00385         // Validate an event type, this does NOT add it to the
00386         // internal registry, only verifies that it is legal (
00387         // e.g. either the ident number is not yet assigned, or it is
00388         // assigned to matching signature text, and the signature
00389         // text is not empty ).
00390 
00391         virtual bool validateType( EventType const & inType ) const = 0;
00392 
00393 private:
00394 
00395         // internal use only accessor for the static methods in the
00396         // helper to use to get the active global instance.
00397 
00398         static IEventManager * Get();
00399 
00400         // These methods are declared friends in order to get access to the
00401         // Get() method. Since there is no other private entity declared
00402         // in this class this does not break encapsulation, but does allow
00403         // us to do this without requiring macros or other older-style
00404         // mechanims.
00405 
00406         friend bool safeAddListener( EventListenerPtr const & inHandler,
00407                                                                  EventType const & inType );
00408         
00409         friend bool safeDelListener( EventListenerPtr const & inHandler,
00410                                                                  EventType const & inType );
00411 
00412         friend bool safeTriggerEvent( Event const & inEvent );
00413 
00414         friend bool safeQueEvent( EventPtr const & inEvent );
00415 
00416         friend bool safeAbortEvent( EventType const & inType,
00417                                                                 bool allOfType = false );
00418 
00419         friend bool safeTickEventManager( unsigned long maxMillis =
00420                                                                 IEventManager::kINFINITE );
00421 
00422         friend bool safeValidateEventType( EventType const & inType );
00423 
00424 };
00425 
00426 // Lastly, these methods are used for easy-access methods to carry
00427 // out basic operations without needing to pass around a pointer-to
00428 // ( or some other construct ) for sharing a global event manager.
00429 
00430 bool safeAddListener( EventListenerPtr const & inHandler,
00431                                           EventType const & inType );
00432         
00433 bool safeDelListener( EventListenerPtr const & inHandler,
00434                                           EventType const & inType );
00435 
00436 bool safeTriggerEvent( Event const & inEvent );
00437 
00438 bool safeQueEvent( EventPtr const & inEvent );
00439 
00440 bool safeAbortEvent( EventType const & inType,
00441                                          bool allOfType /* = false */ );
00442 
00443 bool safeTickEventManager( unsigned long maxMillis
00444                                         /* = IEventManager::kINFINITE */ );
00445 
00446 bool safeValidateEventType( EventType const & inType );
